Award.AwardTitle: Microfluidically-Tunable Metamaterial Lenses for Wideband, High-Power, Phased-Array Applications

Division.LongName: Div Of Electrical, Commun & Cyber Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
The objective of this research is to fundamentally advance the development of affordable, high-power phased-array antenna technology. The approach is to use the recent advances in the areas of microwave metamaterials and microfluidics to develop a new class of high-power-capable, tunable, true-time-delay microwave lenses.

Intellectual Merit: The fundamental tradeoffs that exist between cost, power handling capability, thermal management, and efficiency have hindered the development of high-power, affordable phased-array antenna technology. This project seeks to address these fundamental shortcomings using a previously unexplored interdisciplinary approach. A new class of metamaterials will be used to develop true-time-delay microwave lenses capable of handling very high power levels. A microfluidic mechanism will be used to rapidly reconfigure the lens response and achieve dynamic beam steering in lens-based phased arrays.

Broader Impacts: This project is expected to positively impact the society and the economy by proliferating the use of phased-array technology in future wireless systems that aim at addressing grand societal and economic challenges, including efficient access to the radio spectrum and economically viable solar power transmission. Educational goals of this work are intimately linked to the research objectives and include involvement of underrepresented undergraduate and graduate students in research activities, integration of research into the teaching of engineering at the undergraduate and graduate levels, and development and broad dissemination of research-based educational materials. The research findings of this work will be integrated with existing University of Wisconsin-Madison courses to enhance the undergraduate and graduate engineering curricula.

Intellectual Merits:

Phased-arrays and agile antenna apertures are key building blocks of future wireless systems that aim at addressing grand societal and economic challenges such as enhancing the efficiency with which we access the radio spectrum and the development of 5th generation millimeter-wave communications systems. In this project, we tackled some of the major challenges that exist in the path of development affordable phased-array antennas with the aim of enabling the widespread use of this technology in future wireless systems. In doing so, we used an interdisciplinary, two-prong approach. First, using a new class of sub-wavelength periodic structures referred to as the miniaturized-element frequency selective surfaces (MEFSSs), we developed wideband, true-time-delay, planar microwave lenses and reflectarrays capable of handling high power levels. Secondly, we invented a number of new mechanical reconfiguration techniques for tuning the responses of these devices to allow them to be used in low-complexity, affordable, phased arrays. The specific outcomes of this project are categorized in three categories and are outlined below:

 

  • Sub-wavelength periodic structures: In this area, we developed a number of different miniaturized-element frequency selective surfaces for processing and manipulation of electromagnetic wave fronts in various ways including filtering, phase shifting, time-delaying, and polarization control and conversion. Specifically, we developed single- and dual-band MEFSSs with various responses types and bandwidths, developed spatial filters that can withstand extremely high power levels, developed MEFSSs suitable for stealth and low-observable applications, and developed planar surfaces that convert the polarization of an electromagnetic wave from linear to circular over an extremely wide frequency bandwidth and field of view (e.g. see Fig. Polarization Converter).

 

  • Broadband Microwave Lenses and Reflectarrays: We used the sub-wavelength periodic structures discussed earlier as the building blocks of wideband, true-time-delay microwave lenses and reflectarrays. Using these devices, we developed a number of wideband, high-gain antennas capable of providing one or more beams pointed at different directions in space. We developed antenna types that are particularly suitable for applications such as point-to-point wireless communications, point-to-multi-point wireless communications, and high-power communications and radar systems. Fig. TTD Lens shows a high-power capable, all dielectric, wideband microwave lens.

 

  • Mechanically-Tunable Techniques and Devices: In this area, we developed a number of mechanical tuning techniques for reconfiguration of the responses of the periodic structures and antennas mentioned earlier. Specifically, we developed a microfluidic tuning technique for reconfiguring the responses of large-scale periodic structure and experimentally demonstrated the utility of this technique in various large-scale devices (e.g. see Fig. Fluidically Tunable High-Impedance Surface). We showed that the same microfluidic technique can be used to tune the responses of antenna arrays to obtain beam-steering or frequency tuning technique (e.g. see Fig. Fluidically-Tunable Patch Antenna). Finally, we developed a mechanical tuning technique that uses mechanical flexure to tune the responses of large-scale periodic structures and beam-steerable antennas (e.g. see Fig. Mechanically-Tunable Frequency Selective Surface).
